title: 114_hr3956
content: The Act may be cited as the "VA Health Center Management Stability and Improvement Act". Congress finds that the Department of Veterans Affairs is facing challenges with the management of medical centers, including the frequent turnover of directors due to the inability to recruit permanent candidates. This turnover hinders long-term planning and system management functions. The Department of Veterans Affairs faces challenges with managing medical centers, including frequent turnover of directors hindering long-term planning. The Secretary should develop a plan to recruit permanent directors at centers lacking one. The Department of Veterans Affairs is tasked with developing a plan to hire permanent directors for medical centers facing challenges with frequent turnover hindering long-term planning. The Department of Veterans Affairs must create a plan to hire qualified directors for medical centers lacking permanent leadership, prioritizing those with prolonged vacancies. The plan should set hiring deadlines, address obstacles, and explore opportunities for internal promotions. The Secretary is required to submit this plan to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs within 120 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of the Department of Veterans Affairs must submit a plan within 120 days to hire directors for medical centers lacking permanent leadership. Additionally, semiannual reports listing centers without directors must be submitted every 180 days until January 1, 2018. SEC. 4. COMPLIANCE WITH SCHEDULING REQUIREMENTS. Annual Certification: The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must ensure that each medical facility director certifies annually to be in compliance with scheduling laws and regulations. Waivers are prohibited. Noncompliance requires a report with explanations and actions taken. The director must submit a report to the Secretary explaining noncompliance with scheduling laws and detailing actions taken. Failure to certify results in a prohibition on bonuses for certain officials at the medical facility. Covered officials at medical facilities of the Department include the director, chief of staff, associate director, associate director for patient care, and deputy chief of staff. The Secretary must annually report on facilities certified under subsection (a)(1) and those not certified, including reports submitted under subsection (b). The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must ensure that all directives and policies of the Department apply uniformly to each office or facility. If there are any deviations, the Secretary must notify the Committees on Veterans' Affairs in the House of Representatives and the Senate.
